bestBHT.bht: The threat in Hebrews 3:11 extends beyond the exclusion from the literal land of rest. The promised rest for believers is yet to be fulfilled, aligning with Christ's beatitude. Swearing signifies the certainty of God's punishment, while the correlation between the oath and disobedience emphasizes God's determination and the consequences. The rest refers to the rest given by God, symbolized by Canaan and heavenly rest. Despite the belief that some in the wilderness had no part in the world to come, there were still those who went to heaven despite their sins and provocations.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: the threat extended farther than the exclusion of the unbelieving from the literal land of rest
the rest promised to the believing in its full blessedness was, and is, yet future
Christ's own beatitude (Matthew 5:5) all accord with this
Albert Barnes: God is often represented in the Scriptures as 'swearing' - and usually as swearing by himself, or by his own existence. Of course, this is figurative and denotes a strong affirmation, or a settled and determined purpose.

The word 'if' has this negative meaning in Hebrew, and this meaning is transferred to the Greek word 'if.' It is called 'my rest' here, meaning that it was such rest as God had provided, or such as he enjoyed.

The particular 'rest' referred to here was that of the land of Canaan, but which was undoubtedly regarded as emblematic of the 'rest' in heaven. Into that rest, God solemnly said they should never enter.
John Calvin: The Lord calls the land, where they might have had their dwelling, his rest.
For nowhere can we have a settled dwelling, except where we are fixed by his hand.
By no chastisement could they have been restored to a sound mind, but they continually added new offenses.
Philip Schaff: Hebrews 3:11. So; rather ‘as,’ though without much difference in meaning: the acts corresponded to the punishment is the meaning of ‘as;’ the punishment corresponded to the acts is the meaning of so. The former is the common meaning of the Greek.
Archibald T. Robertson: As I sware (ως ωμοσα). 'Correlating the oath and the disobedience' (Vincent)."
They shall not enter (ε εισελευσοντα). Future middle of εισερχομα with ε as an anacoluthon for the Hebrew im (not)."
Into my rest (εις την καταπαυσιν μου). Old word from καταπαυω (Hebrews 4:8), to give rest, in LXX, in N.T. only in Acts 7:49; Hebrews 3:11-4.
John Gill: Swearing is ascribed to God, to show the certainty of the thing spoken of; as of mercies, when he swears in love, and by his holiness; so here, of punishment, when he swears in wrath, in indignation, in sore displeasure, and the threatened evil is irrevocable and inevitable.

into the land of Canaan, called God's rest, because he promised it, and gave it to the Israelites as their rest; and where he himself had a place of rest; and where he gave the Messiah, the author of peace and rest; and which was a type of heaven, that rest from toil and labour, which remains for the people of God.

for the Jews say, 'the generation of the wilderness have no part in the world to come:' but this seems too harsh, for doubtless there were many who died in the wilderness, that went safe to heaven, notwithstanding all their sins and provocations.

bhtAttempts.bht: The threat in Hebrews 3:11 extended beyond mere exclusion from the land of rest; it also encompassed the future promise of rest for believers. This promise of rest is in line with Christ's beatitude in Matthew 5:5. The correlation between the oath and disobedience signifies God's determination and the consequences for not entering into His rest. Rest here refers to the rest given by God and can be seen as both the land of Canaan and a symbol of heavenly rest. The certainty of God's punishment is emphasized through the act of swearing, highlighting the irrevocability of the threatened evil. While the Jews believed that the generation of the wilderness had no part in the world to come, it is important to note that some who died in the wilderness still found their way to heaven, despite their sins and provocations.

The threat in Hebrews 3:11 extends beyond exclusion from the land of rest. The promised rest is yet to come and aligns with Christ's beatitude. The oath correlates with disobedience, signifying God's determination and the consequences. The rest refers to the rest given by God, symbolized by Canaan and heavenly rest. God's punishment is certain as shown in swearing. Some who died in the wilderness still found their way to heaven despite their sins.

The threat in Hebrews 3:11 extends beyond exclusion from the literal land of rest. The promise of rest for believers is yet to be fulfilled, aligning with Christ's beatitude. The correlation between the oath and disobedience emphasizes God's determination and the consequences. The rest refers to the rest given by God, symbolized by Canaan and heavenly rest. Swearing signifies the certainty of God's punishment. Although some believe that those in the wilderness had no part in the world to come, there were those who died but still went to heaven despite their sins and provocations.

Swearing signifies the certainty of God's punishment, while the correlation between the oath and disobedience emphasizes God's determination and the consequences. The rest refers to the rest given by God, symbolized by Canaan and heavenly rest. Despite the belief that some in the wilderness had no part in the world to come, there were still those who went to heaven despite their sins and provocations.

The threat of Hebrews 3:11 extends beyond exclusion from the literal land of rest, encompassing the promise of future rest for believers. Swearing emphasizes the certainty of God's punishment, while the correlation between the oath and disobedience highlights His determination and the consequences. The rest signifies the rest given by God, symbolized by Canaan and heavenly rest. Though some believe that those in the wilderness had no part in the world to come, there were still those who went to heaven despite their sins and provocations.
